l  The  order  derived  its  name  from  the  Abbey  of 
Cluni,  in  Burgundy,  the  first  and  always  the  chief 
house  of  the  brotherhood.  So  magnificent  was  that 
foundation,  that  after  the  first  council  of  Lyons  in 
1245,  we  are  told  the  Abbey  received  within  its  waUs 
at  onc  time,  the  Pope,  (Innocent  IV.)  Baldwin  Em-

Arragon,  the  two  Patriarchs  of  Constantinople  and 
Antioch,  twelve  cardiuals,  tliree  archbishops,  fifteen 
bishops,  six  earls,  and  many  olher  great  lords  and  ab- 
bots, — and  that  without  depriving  the  brethren  of  their 
chambers,  their  refectory,  chapter  house,  and  other 
ordinary  apartments. 

The  iMonastery  of  Wenlock  was  peopled  from  the 
Priory  of  La  Charite  on  tiie  banks  of  the  Loire,  the 
first  in  rank  of  the  Priories  of  the  Cluniac  order  ;  and 
theperfectly  organized  subordination  preserved  through 
all  the  institutions  of  this  great  society,  rendered  it  ne- 
cessary  that  the  new  colony  should  have  the  sanction 
not  only  of  its  immediate  parent,  but  of  the  niother 
church,  and  the  liead  of  the  order.  For  explanation 
of  one  or  two  of  the  following  documents,  it  may  be 
proper  to  mention  that  Bemo  the  founder  of  the  oider, 
and  St.  Odo  his  successor  in  the  Abbacy  of  Cluny, 
were  held  in  especial  respect  and  veneration  by  the

Wenlock  ^'as  founded  by  Roger  the  great  Earl  of  Montgomery,  on  the  ruins,  it  was 
said,  of  a  former  convent,  Mhere  Milburga,  grand-daughter  of  Penda  Saxon  king  of 
Mercia,  had  presided  and  was  buried  in  the  odour  of  sanctity.  Her  tonib,  which 
had  been  neglected  and  forgotten  since  the  coming  in  of  the  Normans,  was  accidentally 
discovered  in  building  the  new  monastery,  by  the  balsamic  perfume  issuing  from  it ; 
and  numerous  miracles  wrought  by  her  relics,  with  crowds  of  pilgrims  flocking  to  her 
shrine,  soon  brought  the  Saxon  saint  and  consequently  her  place  of  interment  into  such 
repute,  that  the  foreign  monks  conciliated  the  natives  by  taking  her  for  their  patroness. 
A  century  after,  the  colony  from  Wenlock  carried  vvitli  it  to  Paisley  the  same  reverence 
for  its  patron  saint,  and  the  ne^v  monastery  \»as  dedicated  to  lier,  togetlier  with  Saint 
James,  the  patron  of  an  okler  church  where  the  new  monks  liad  flrst  settled,  and  Saint 
Mirinus,  Bishop  and  Confessor,  whose  histor}'  also  speaks  the  country  of  his  origin. 
This  other  peculiar  patron  Saint  of  Paisley  was  educated,  says  the  Scottish  Brc- 
viary,"  under  Saint  Congalkis  in  the  Abbey  of  Bangour.  Resisting  the  temptations  of 
wealth  and  rank  to  which  he  was  born,  he  devoted  himself  to  a  monastic  life,  and  be- 
came  Prior  of  the  Monastery  of  Bangour,  under  the  Abbot  Congallus.  Nothing  more 
of  his  life  is  added  by  this  apocryphal  chronicle,  except  the  details  of  a  feiv  of  his  mi- 
racles,  which  are  not  in  general  distinguished  by  much  origiuality.  At  one  tiroe,  a 
holy  Bishop,  a  guest  in  the  abbey,  requiring  milk  propter  molUorcm  svi  corporis  qiia- 
Utafcm,  when  there  was  none  in  the  monastery,  it  was  miraculously  supplied  by  the 
intervention  of  Mirinus.  On  another  occasion,  he  restored  by  his  prayers  one  of  his 
brethren  who  had  fidlen  down  from  extreme  labour  and  thirst,  after  he  had  lain  lifeles» 
for  many  hours.  A  third  exertiou  of  the  Saint's  miraculous  powers  is  somewhat  more 
singular.  Travelling  on  a  religious  mission,  he  arrivcd  at  the  castle  of  the  King  of 
Ireland,  and  prayed  to  be  admitted.  It  happened  that  the  queen  was  then  in  the  paius 
of  childbirth,  and  on  that  account  or  for  other  reasons  the  Saint  was  denied  admit- 
tance  and  treated  with  disrespect ;  upon  which,  departing  in  indignation,  he  intreated 
of  heaven  that  the  King  niight  suffer  tlie  pains  of  laboiu-  instead  of  his  wife.  This 
fearful  malediction  was  immediately  fulfilled,  so  that  for  three  days  and  nights  the 
miserable  monarch  was  heard  by  all  the  subjects  of  his  kingdom  to  cry  incessantly  like 
a  woman  in  travail,  until  at  length,  fiiiding  all  remedies  of  physicians  vain,  he  took 
means  to  appease  the  saint,  and  was  by  him  delivered  from  his  sufferings.  We  are 
not  informed  when  Mirinus  became  a  bishop,   nor  even  at  what  time  he  lived,''  but  the

Tliougli  munificently  endowed  by  its  founder,  wlio  also  purchased  by  a  grant  of

canonical  benediction.^  Repeated  complaiuts  were  made  of  this  grievance,  not  witliout 
allegations  that  Humbald  the  prior  of  AVenlock  liad  overreached  the  Steward  iii  their 
transaction,  and  had  at  least  concealed  the  defect  in  the  constitution  of  the  convent.

entreaties  of  the  Bishop  of  Glasgow  and  other  Scottish  bishops  then  at  Lyons,  and  con- 
.^ented  to  the  election  of  an  abbot  by  the  monks  of  Paisley,  which  privilege  had  been

king  and  Walter  bisliop  of  Glasgow.  A  century  later  (probably  in  tlie  year  1334,)

The  property  of  the  Abbey,  derived  chiefly  from  the  grants  of  the  first  three  Stewards

An  imperfect  and  inaccurate  list  of  the  successive  Priors  and  Abbots  of  Paisley,'  is 
given  by  Crawfurd  in  his  History  of  Renfrewshire,  and  with  only  less  inaccuracy  by 
tather  Hay  in  a  breve  chronicoii  appended  to  his  transcript  of  the  Chartulary.t  John 
Hamilton,  the  last  ordained  Abbot,  elected  in  1525,  resigued  the  abbacy  on  being  raised 
to  tlie  Archbishoprick  of  St  Andrews,  in  favour  of  his  nephew  the  Lord  Claud  Ha- 
milton,  fourth  son  of  James  second  Earl  of  Arran,  wlio  after  an  interrupted  possession 
as  commendator,  had  a  charter  oi  the  Lordship  of  Paisley  with  the  dignity  of  a  Lord 
of  Parliament,  29th  July  1587.  The  Abbey  and  Lordship  continucd  the  property  of 
his  descendants,  till  sold  by  James  second  Earl  of  Abercorn  to  the  Earl  of  Angus,  from 
whom  it  was  purcliased  by  Williara  tirst  Lord  Cochrane  of  Dundonald  in  1653  for 
L.  160,000  Scots.  The  family  of  Dundonald  held  the  Lordship,  and  chiefly  resided  at 
Paisley,  for  more  than  a  century,  mitil  in  1764  it  was  again  sold  by  Thomas  eigiith  Earl 
of  Dundonald,  to  James  eighth  Earl  of  Abercorn,  ia  whose  family  it  stiil  continues.

H  It  is  in  these  terms,  "  jMy  best  acknowledgements 
are  ever  due  to  the  Right  Honourable  John  Earl  of 
Dundonald,  who  was  pleased  to  allow  me  the  perusal 
of  the  Register  of  the  Blonastery  of  Pasly,  by  which 
I  had  some  special  advantages  of  discovering  the  anti- 
quities  of  the  most  of  the  noble  and  ancient  families  in 
the  Shire  of  Renfrew,  and  of  the  illustrious  family  of 
Stewarl.  Having  so  often  mentioned  the  Register  or 
Chartulary  of  Pasly,  I  shall  presume  so  far  upon  the 
reader's  patience,  as  to  give  a  brief  account  of  the  same. 
In  the  old  monasteries  of  Scotland  tliere  were  three  sort 
of  Register  books  ;  as,  I.  A  general  one,  which  by 
way  of  anuals  or  chronicle,  gavc  the  yearly  occurrences 


relating  to  the  public.  II.  Their  obiiuaries,  wherein 
were  recorded  the  tinies  of  the  death  and  the  places  of 
intemient  of  tlieir  Abbols,  Priors,  and  othergreat  men 
of  their  respective  houses,  and  tlieir  cliief  bencfactors. 

III.  Their  Chartulury  or  Register,  whereiu  were  re- 
corded  the  charters  of  the  Kings,  and  otlier  grcat  men, 
buUs  of  tlie  Popes,  and  the  more  private  granis  of  in. 
feriour  benefaciois,  which  had  passed  in  iheir  favours, 
such  as  this  book  I  am  now  to  give  account  of,  which 
is  a  large  folio,  all  writ  on  Lombard  paptr,  in  a  fair 
legible  hand.  The  first  leaf  begins  with  an  alphabe- 
tical  index  of  all  the  charters  therein  coniained.  Thcn 
follows  the  charter  of  foundation,  wliich  is  confirmed 
by  the  Pope's  bull,  with  another  from  King  William, 
as  also  several  privileges  and  exemplions  from  the 
bishops  of  Glasgow,  Argile,  and  the  isles.  Then  we 
have through  tlie whole book proniiscuously,  Popesbulls, 
grants  from  the  Sovereigns,  and  donalions  of  the  Hi"h 
Stewards  of  Scolland,  who  were  its  patrons  and  greatest 
benefactors.  In  the  101  leaf  we  have  catta  erectionis 
villte  de  Paslelo  in  liberum  burgum,  by  King  Janies 

IV.  anno  1488  ;  the  grounds  of  the  erection  are  his 
devotion  to  St.  Mirin  tlie  holy  confessor,  and  his  high 
love  and  respect  to  the  venerable  father,  George  Shaw 
Abbot  of  the  Monastery  of  Pasly.  Then  we  have  se- 
veral  granis  by  the  Abbots  to  their  vassals,  brought  down 
totheyear  1645."  It  may  serve  as  a  useful  waming 
against  placing  implicit  confidence  in  this  author's  ac- 
curacy,  to  point  out  the  singular  combination  of  mis- 
takes  contained  in  this  passage.  The  general  account 
of  the  three  soits  of  registers,  which  cannot  be  held  as 
apphcable  to  all  Scottish  monasteries,  nor  perhaps  was 
exactly  true  of  any,  is  copied  verbatim  from  Nicol- 
son's  Historical  Library.  Witli  regard  to  the  particular 
description   of  the  Chartulaiy  of  Paisley,  which  from 

its  minuteness  might  be  expecled   to  be  accurate, so 

far  from  being  a  large  folio,  it  is,  although  ccrtainly 
afolio  iu  shape,  of  so  small  a  size,  as  to  lead  Father 
Hay,  as  we  have  seen,  to  describe  it  as  a  gtiarto  ,•  next, 
the  index,  which  begins  at  the  fiist  leaf,  (and  which  is 
printed  under  the  title  of  Tabula,)  is  not  in  alphabetical 
arrangenient,  but  iu  the  order  of  tlie  position  of  the 
charters ;    neither  is  it   immediately  followed   by   the 


well-known  antiquary.  In  the  forraer  quotations,  the  folios  referred  to  coincide  with 
those  of  oiir  Register :  in  the  latter,  the  pages  are  those  of  Father  Hay^s  trauscript, 
which  seems  to  have  been  acquired  by  Macfarlan,  and  to  have  passed  with  his  other 
collections  into  the  library  of  tlie  Faculty  of  Advocates. 

It  is  certain  then  that  our  manuscript  is  the  sajne  which  has  been  consulted  and 
quoted  by  Scottish  historical  writers  as  the  original  andgenuine  Chartulary  of  Paisley; 
and  although  it  may  be  presumed  that  a  house  so  old  and  wealtliy  must  liave  had  earlier 
coUections  of  its  muniments,  yet  from  the  diaracter  in  which  it  is  written,  approaching 
8o  near  to  the  date  of  many  of  the  deeds  recorded  in  it,  any  such  older  registers  must 
have  been  defective  in  comparison  with  this,  wliich  presents  the  charters  and  privileges

The  record,  unfortunately,  by  no  means  deserves  to  stand  so  high  for  accuracy 
and  care  of  formation,  as  it  does  for  genuineness  and  authentieity.  The  scribe  em- 
ployed  was  evidently  ignorant  of  the  language  in  which  he  wrote  and  careless  of  ortho- 
graphy  and  of  correctuess  of  transcribing.  In  cases  where  tlie  documents  recorded  are 
liable  to  suspicion,  perhaps  his  simplicity  may  be  considered  a  favourable  circumstance 
in  estimating  his  credibility.  Fortunately  there  are  still  in  our  power  other  means  of 
judging  of  the  general  fidelity  of  this  record.  It  has  been  already  mentioned,  that

of  that  family  is  supported  by  an  exchange  which  took  place  between  the  Priory  of 
Wenloc  and  the  first  Steward.  He  had  originally  covenanted  to  give  the  house  of 
Wenloc,  in  consideration  of  its  obtaining  certain  privileges  for  his  new  foundation,  a 
tenement  in  his  burgh  of  Renfrew,  with  extensive  rights  of  fishing.i'  This  grant 
was  probably  found  inconveniently  distant  from  the  monastery,  and  the  parties  agreed 
to  an  excambion  of  the  possessions  in  Kenfrew,  for  property  in  Meuewde, — a  name 
which  seems  to  bear  no  affinity  to  auy  place  in  Scotland,  nor  does  the  Priory  of 
Wenloc  appear  to  have  continued  to  possess  any  property  in  tliis  kingdom.  It  is  pro- 
bable  that  the  situation  of  the  property  given  in  exchange  to  the  Prior  was  not  very 
distant  from  his  monastery,  and  if  a  conjecture  may  be  hazarded  on  so  slight  a  founda- 
tion  as  tlie  similarity  of  names,  that  place  may  have  been  Mynyv,  the  ancient  name 
of  the  Welsh  Bishopric  of  St.  Davids,  written  in  English  Mcnew,  aud  Latinized 
Menevia  ;  any  of  which  forms  might,  in  the  hands  of  an  ignorant  transcriber,  assume 
the  shape  of  the  name  in  our  Register.  It  is  by  no  means  improbable,  that  tlie  Lords  of 
Oswestry  had  possessions  round  St.  Davids,  where  a  powerful  colony  of  the  Norraan 
conquerors  of  England  had  established  themselves  before  the  date  of  this  transaction.^

The  family  of  De  Insulis  commands  our  iuterest,  not  more  from  its  great  power 
and  consequence,  than  from  tlie  impenetrable  mystery  which  involves  its  origin,  the 
obscurity  and  doubt  attending  its  extinction,  and  the  clashiug  pretensions  of  the  nume- 
rous  races  which  have  parcelled  out  its  possessions,  to  be  held  its  descendants  and  repre- 
sentatives.  E.vercising  exteusive  sovereign  power  and  frequently  asserting  a  regal 
style,  those  princes  appear  in  history,  at  loug  intervals,  treating  almost  on  equal  terms 
with  the  greatest  crowned  heads,  wliile  in  the  intermediate  times,  their  remote  exis- 
tence  is  marked  ouly  by  the  ravages  of  tlieir  fierce  followers  on  everj-  coast  where  a 
prey  was  to  be  taken.  It  is  not  to  be  hoped  that  any  new  light  can  be  thrown  on 
the  history  of  a  race  which  has  been  so  eagerly  discussed,  by  the  publication  of  a  record 
already  so  famlliar  to  the  historian  aud  the  genealogist  as  the  Chartulary  of  Paisley  ; 
but  it  may  tend  to  the  encreased  accuracy  of  fiiture  discussions  of  tlie  subject,  to  pre- 
sent,  in  an  authentic  shape,  charters  of  four  successive  generations  of  that  great  family.a 

These  charters  are  also  interesting  from  their  substance  and  singular  terms ;  the

uually  from  every  house  from  which  smoke  issues  within  their  territories,  while  Fonia,

Tlic  connexion  existing  between  the  Abbeys  of  Paisley  and  Crosraguel,  which  led 
to  the  iusertion  of  the  succeeding  writs,*  is  somewhat  obscure.  It  appears  that  Dun- 
can  Earl  of  Carric,  (who  was  allied  to  Walter  tlie  first  Steward  by  the  marriage  of 
their  children,)  founded  and  endowed  the  house  of  Crosraguel  for  monks  of  Paisley, 
and  so  richly  tliat  the  new  colony  aspired  immediately  to  independence,  while  the 
niother  house  endeavoured  to  keep  it  as  a  cell  or  oratorlum  to  be  enjoyed  by  brethren 
of  their  convent,  and  under  their  immediate  control.  The  dispute  was  ineffectually 
referred  to  the  Bishop  of  Glasgow  as  diocesan,  and  finally  settled,  probably  by  a  papal 
(•ommission,  fl-hich  seems  to  have  secured  the  independence  of  Crosraguel,  reserving  to 
Paisley  a  right  of  visitation'  and  three  churches  of  Carric™ 

After  the  writs  relative  to  Crosraguel,  there  follow  two  bulls,  one  by  Benedict  XI. 
granting  to  the  Abbot  of  Paisley  tlie  privilege  of  using  the  mitre,  ring,  and  other  epis- 
copal  insignia,  and  of  granting  the  benediction  after  service  in  absence  of  a  Bishop ; » 
the  other  the  duplicate  of  a  buU  of  Pope  Alexander  III.  which  occurred  previously, » 
:uk1  which  is  repeated  only  to  give  the  additional  authentication  of  the  subscriptions  of 
the  Pope  and  Cardinals.P  An  instrument  of  the  settlement  of  the  marches  betwecn 
Caldorhauch  and  tlie  Abbey  lands  of  Bar,?  and  two  writs  regarding  property  in  Glas- 
gow,''  conclude  tlie  record  of  real  deeds  contained  in  tlie  Register.  The  remain- 
der,«  which  are  not  contained  in  the  original  table  of  contents,  appear  rather  to  have 
been  styles,  inserted  for  tlie  convenience  of  reference  on  the  blank  leaves  of  the  chartu- 
lary,  than  copies  of  really  existing  documents. 

Composed  of  sucli  materials,  free  at  least  from  all  suspicion  of  wilful  vitiation,  the 
cliartulary  of  Paisley  presents  one  important  distinction  and  superiority  over  the  greater 
part  of  the  registers  of  religious  houses,  in  embodying  the  wlxole  of  the  deeds  recorded, 
^\ithout  omitting,  as  in  too  many  cases,  the  condusions  of  charters  and  tlieir  witnesses. 
This  is  not  merely  serviceabJe  in  aiding  the  researches  of  geuealogists.  In  chartei-s  of 
liioh  antiquity,  where  dates  are  rarely  given,  it  funiishes  tlie  only  means  of  approxi- 
mating  to  the  time  of  granting  the  deed,  and,  which  is  even  a  higher  advantage,  fur- 
nislies  numerous  criteria  by  whicli  to  detect  any  imposition,  and  to  establish  the  authen- 
ticity  of  genulne  documents.  So  successfully  has  the  study  of  this  department  of  an- 
tiquities  been  prosecuted  in  France  and  in  England,  that  probably  uo  charter  with  a 
\m"  list  of  witncsses  can  be  so  ingeniously  forged  as  to  escape  detection,  and  althougli 
the  same  degree  of  lcarning  has  not  been  brought  to  bear  upon  Scottisli  diplomacy, 
aiul  many  of  the  tests  are  lost  in  the  formation  of  a  register,  yet  great  additional 
A»'eight  must  in  all  cases  atteud  a  charter  where  the  witnesscs  are  fully  cxpressed.

In  bringiug  forward  the  first,  and  what  froni  several  caiises  may  be  esteemed  one  of 
the  most  interesting,  of  the  Scottish  Chartiilaries,  it  may  be  permitted  shortly  to  draw 
the  attention  of  those  who  have  not  made  them  their  study,  to  the  information  to  be 
derived  from  this  class  of  records.  Their  historical  importance  is  very  generally 
admitted.  The  numerous  cliarters  of  our  earlier  kings,  not  elsewhere  preserved,  and 
those  of  persons  only  second  to  them  in  rank  and  interest,  present  the  most  authen- 
tic  materials  of  the  history  of  a  dark  period,  in  which  may  be  traced  the  foun- 
dation  and  early  progress  of  our  remarkable  constitution.  Doubtful  dates  are  fixed  ; 
the  position  and  mutual  relation  of  the  actors  on  the  historical  stage  are  ascertained ; 
incidental  mention  occurs  of  contemporary  liistorical  events ;  if  these  authentic  doeu- 
ments  do  not  furnish  a  connected  detail  of  affairs,  they  afFord  the  surest  nieans  of  testing 
the  accuracy  of  the  accounts  of  the  chronicler  and  annalist,  and  frequently  the  most 
satisfactory  correction  of  their  errors.  In  the  early  history  of  all  countries, — but  espe- 
cially  of  one  whose  history  has  been  obscured  not  so  much  even  by  the  loss  of  its 
national  records,  as  by  the  folly  of  writers  attempting  to  supply  that  loss  by  fabulous 
inventions, — it  is  of  the  first  consequence  to  assemble  as  a  foundation  all  historical 
facts,  however  trivial ;  and  the  collector  will  ofteu  be  astonished  to  find  these,  singly 
so  unimportant,  when  placed  together,  arranging  themselves  in  the  lucid  order  and 
fiiU  detail  of  true  history.  But,  however  necessary  as  a  ground-work,  the  detail  of 
public  events  does  not  in  truth  form  the  most  important  part  of  the  early  history  of  a 
people.  To  ascertain  the  first  recognition  of  individual  and  natlonal  rights ;  to  trace 
the  rising  of  the  frce  husbandman  out  of  the  serf  chained  to  the  soil,  and  the  growth  of 
societies  for  mutual  support  and  protection  against  ^'iolence  ;  to  mark  the  steps  of  ad- 
A-ancement  towards  complete  security  of  property,  and,  dependent  upon  it,  the  rise  of 
eommerceand  theingenious  machinery  devised  for  transferring  and  bequeathing  wealth  ; 
to  study  the  mutual  relation  betweeu  the  sovereign  and  the  subject,  not  merely  as  the 
governor  and  the  governed,  but  as  the  great  lord  of  the  soil  and  the  vassal  bound  by 
his  tenure  to  do  him  service  ;  in  a  word,  to  observe  the  careful  building  up  of  the  pile 
of  modern  society,  the  antique  and  cumbrous  decorations  of  which  are  now  falling 
fast  asunder, — such  are  the  legitimate  objects  of  history,  at  a  period  wheu  tlie  motives 
of  the  actors,  the  policy  of  statesmen,  the  causes  of  happy  or  adverse  fortuue,  and 
the  resTilts  of  difFerent  lines  of  conduct,  can  hardly  be  guessed  at, — while  the  commonplace 
historian  finds  nothing  to  record  but  a  rapid  and  confused  succession  of  questionable 
kings,  attempts  of  usurpers,  wars  of  hostile  nations  marked  by  the  usual  details  of  vio- 
lence  and  rapine,  or  battles  of  kindred  tribes  where  eacli  claims  the  victory,  and  «iiere 
now  the  chief  dispute  is  who  were  the  combatants. 

The  student  who  takes  an  extensive  view  of  the  field  of  early  history,  will  not  fail  tu 


dorive  benefit  from  such  materials  as  compose  the  Scottish  chartiilaries.  He  M'ill  find 
there  the  oldest  writings  that  have  bcen  preserved,  and  some  that  may  be  fairly  esteem- 
ed  contemporary  with  the  first  grants  of  land,  perhaps  with  the  first  use  of  writing,  in 
Scotlaud, — containing  the  details  of  the  foundation  of  religious  houses,  which  may  be 
called  the  first  step  in  civilization,  and  markiug  their  rapid  acquisition  of  «'ealtli,  until 
the  church  accumulated  property  disproportioned  to  the  uarrowncss  of  the  country,  and 
formed  a  counterbalance  to  the  wliole  power  of  the  aristocracy.  Such  of  tliese  records 
as  extend  back  to  a  high  antiquity,  afford  the  surest  information  on  the  much  vexed 
question  of  the  successive  settlers  of  the  different  districts  of  Scotland ;  and  if  they  do 
not  furnish  a  consistent  and  unimpugnable  system,  will  at  least,  if  fairly  studied,  enable 
us  to  avoid  the  confident  and  rash  assertions  of  contending  theorists,  while  M'e  trace 
with  sufficieut  accuracy  the  gi'adual  disappcarance  of  the  native  inferior  race  before  the 
more  energetic  strangers,  and  the  partial  prevalence  and  more  unaccountable  extinction 
of  a  system  of  servitude  exercised  by  the  new  lords  over  the  origiual  inhabitants  of  tlie  soil. 
The  incidental  occurrence  of  traits  of  manners,  and  notices  of  the  mode  of  life  of  a 
jteriod  unillustrated  by  contemporary  litei'ature,  gives  an  interest  to  these  records  perhaps 
even  greater  thau  the  occasional  mention  of  public  events.  In  particular,  they  form  a 
mine  of  unexplored  materials  for  illustrating  the  monastic  life,  in  times  when  the  mo- 
nastery  furnished  not  only  the  statesman,  the  lawyer,  the  chronicler,  and  the  kceper  of 
the  cousciences  of  the  people,  but  the  only  architects,  gardenors,  and  rural  improvers,  as 
well  as  probably  the  cliief  artists  and  artisans.'  While  the  grants  of  property  bring  us 
more  immediately  into  contact  with  the  lords  of  the  soil,  we  meet  at  the  sarae  time  with 
miuute  descriptions  of  the  dwellings  of  the  agrlcultural  population,  intimations  of  their 
inodes  of  tillage  and  pasturage,  the  early  formation  of  roads  and  bridges,  the  vehicles 
aud  modes  of  conveyauce  aud  travelling,  the  customs,  privileges,  and  restrictions  of  hunt- 
iiig  and  fishing — at  a  time  ■«•hcu  the  former  was  the  distinction  of  the  noble,  and  tlie

The  lawyer  has  long  recoguised  tliese  Church  Registers  as  valuable  collectious  of 
ancient  styles,  even  whea  a  portiou  of  the  record  was  not  set  apart  for  that  purpose. 
The  mode  of  conveyauce  aud  trausmission  of  property  iu  early  times,  showing,  by  its 
similarity  to  the  couveyaucing  of  England  aud  the  continent  of  Europe,  a  commou 
and  certaiuly  an  Italian  origin ;  the  gradual  developmeut  of  the  feudal  teuures ;  the 
discussion  aud  settlement  of  legal  disputes  ;  the  scattered  notices  of  forgotten  courts  aud 
judicatures,  and  their  forms  of  procedure  often  wonderfully  systematic  and  acciu-ate, 
coutrasted  with  the  wordy  and  involved  style  of  church  forms  in  the  century  preceding 
tlie  Reformation, — preseut  very  curious  subjects  of  stud}'  for  the  legal  autiijuary  ;  while, 
to  the  student  of  language,  these  transcripts,  themselves  of  venerable  antiquity,  of  docu- 
meuts  far  more  early  than  any  other  records,  give  valuable  assistance.  The  names  of 
the  great  features  of  the  country,  ^vitli  the  minuter  divisions  aud  laudmarks  contain- 
ed  in  bounding  charters  preserving  the  original  orthography,  the  frefjuent  occurreuce  of 
descriptious  and  phrases  iu  the  vulgar  langriage  of  the  district,  accompanied  sometimes 
with  translations  iuto  Latin,  may  be  said  to  allow  us  to  trace  our  strangely  mixed 
language  to  one  at  least  of  its  great  sources ;  for  these,  in  conjunction  with  the  re- 
ciprocal  adoption  of  surnames  from  laud,  and  the  nomenclature  of  places  from  their  early 
settlers,  carry  us  back  to  the  first  intercourse  between  our  country  and  the  Norman 
eonquerors  of  England,  ■while,  in  remote  districts,  we  seem  to  observe  traces  of  earlier 
German  or  Scandiua^'ian  settlers,  pushing  back  the  native  inhabitants,  and  importing 
their  gpeech  as  well  as  their  manuers,  arts  and  arms.

tempt  not  altogether  justly,  in  part  from  the  base  purposes  to  which  it  is  occasionally 
turned,  but  more  from  its  being  so  frequentlj-  raised  into  tlie  importance  of  au  end  and 
object  of  research  instead  of  sei-ving  as  a  road  of  conne.xion  and  guidance  to  the  his- 
toriau,  the  antiquary  aud  the  chronologist.  Without  -wishing  to  claim  undue  impor- 
tauce  for  a  very  captivating  pursuit,  it  may  be  questioned  whether  those  who  so  mucli 
imdervalue  the  study  of  the  succession  of  families,  have  sufficiently.considered  its  iise-

fulncss  in  fiHlng  up  the  meagre  details  of  early  history.  Forming  their  opinions  from  the 
working  of  civiHzed  society,  they  overlook  how  much  depends,  among  a  rude  people, 
npou  the  influence  of  individual  character  and  actions,  as  well  as  the  necessity  of  draw- 
ing  from  the  more  definite  facts  of  family  history,  in  conjunction  with  the  ascertained 
average  length  of  life,  an  accuracy  of  dates  and  of  the  calculation  of  epochs,  which  will 
in  vain  he  sought  for  in  the  ancient  chronicler. 

It  must  not  be  supposed  from  the  Chartularies  being  thus  spoken  of  in  the  aggregate, 
that  these  records  are  of  tlie  same  degree  of  authority,  or  of  nearly  equal  weight.  Tlie 
Registers  of  Scottish  religious  houses  may  be  said  to  hold  all  ranks  from  the  full  evi- 
dence  of  a  record  of  high  antiquit)^  corroborated  by  tlie  preservation  of  many  of  the 
original  documents  from  which  it  had  been  constructcd,  to  the  questionable  authority 
of  a  twice  or  thrice  copied  manuscript,  of  which  the  materials  have  altogether  perished. 
Although  the  subject  of  the  latter  may  be,  of  its  nature,  as  important  as  that  of  the  for- 
mer,  it  is  of  course  less  interesting  and,  for  maiiy  of  the  objects  of  study  that  have  been 
pointed  out,  infinitely  less  useful ;  and  perhaps  this  distinction  afFords  the  best  rule  for 
the  mode  of  publishing  these  records.  Where  the  manuscript  is  of  sufficient  antiquity 
to  claim  somewhat  of  the  authority  of  a  fl-riting  contemporary  with  the  most  important 
deeds  recorded, — still  more  where  the  original  writs  or  part  of  them  are  preser^^ed,  it 
seems  to  be  the  editor's  duty  to  give,  as  nearly  as  printing  will  allow,  a  correct  represent- 
ation  of  the  words  and  letters  used  by  the  writer,  M'ithout  supplying  or  lengthening,  and 
without  the  gloss  of  conjectural  punctuation,  that  the  authority  of  tlie  record  itself  may 
be  transferred  to  the  publication.  On  the  other  hand,  when  the  manuscript  is  a  com- 
paratively  recent  transcript,  not  approaching  the  orthogi'aphy  of  the  origiual  documents, 
and  pointed  iguorantly  or  rashly,  it  appears  absurd  to  adopt  the  imperfections  which 
add  nothing  to  its  authority  or  character  of  genuineness.  Although  the  Chartulary  of 
Paisley  boasts  a  respectable  antiquity,  it  evidently  falls  under  the  latter  class.  The 
writer  has  not  pretended  to  represent  the  orthography  of  his  earlier  materials ;  the  sys- 
tem  of  pointing,  as  well  as  the  forms  of  contraction,  are  uuiform,  from  the  chartei's  of 
the  reign  of  Malcolm  IV.  down  to  the  latest  deeds  entered  in  the  Register.  It  appear- 
ed  in  this  instance,  thcrcfore,  to  be  desirahle  to  prefer  the  meaniug  of  the  writer  where 
that  was  obvious,  to  his  errors  of  negligence  or  evident  misconceptions  of  his  original, 
and  so  far  as  possible  to  make  him  furnish  his  own  correction,  by  collating  with  the 
faulty  passage  the  same  deed  or  the  same  formula  occurring  in  a  difFerent  part  of  his 
compilation. 

As  the  manifest  errors  of  the  manuscript  have  in  many  instances  been  thus  silently 
superseded  iu  the  text,  by  'what  appeared  to  be  a  more  correct  and  intelligible  reading,  it 
has  been  deemed  fit  to  annex  a  list  of  all  sucli  corrections.  In  other  cases  where  the 
reading  of  the  manuscript,  although  apparently  erroneous,  bas  been  adopted  in  the  text. 


it  has  been  thought  adviseable  to  insert  it  in  tlie  List,  with  the  siiggestlon  of  a  preferable 
reading,  which  will  serve  at  least  to  indicate  that  the  apparent  error  of  text  has  not 
been  the  result  of  oversight  or  uegligence.  In  a  considerable  uumber  of  iustances, 
whlle  the  words  of  the  origiual  have  been  suffered  to  remain,  that  which  appeared  to  be 
the  true  or  more  inteUigible  readiug  has  been  also  inserted  in  the  text,  within  brackets, 
and  frequently  ^vliere  tlie  sense  M'as  incomplete,  one  or  more  words  have  been  sup- 
plied  from  a  similar  document  occurring  in  a  different  part  of  the  work,  distinguished 
in  the  same  way  by  brackets,  aud  as  the  reader  has  thus  been  put  on  his  guard,  the 
introduction  of  these  into  the  List  of  corrections  has  been  deemed  unnecessary. 

Th€  table  of  contents,  priuted  accurately  from  the  mannscript,  has  beeu  as  in  the 
original  prefixed  to  the  Register,  and  is  made  to  serve  the  double  purpose  of  a  refe- 
rence  to  the  pages  of  the  printed  work,  and  the  means  of  comparing  them  with  the 
corresponding  folios  of  the  original.  With  more  questionable  utility,  the  date,  certain 
or  conjectural,  or  an  approximation  to  the  date  of  each  charter,  has  been  affixed 
to  its  entry  in  the  table,  within  brackets.  These  have  been  adjusted  with  considerable 
care,  and  may  be  of  use  to  the  general  reader.  The  more  accurate  iuvestigator  will 
not  take  such  facts  on  tlie  authority  of  conjecture.  Much  is  still  M'anting,  and  much 
will  assuredly  be  done  by  the  researches  of  future  antiquaries,  and  the  publication  of 
other  records,  to  facilitate  and  give  accuracy  to  what  is  at  present  a  laborious  and 
unsatisfactory  process.

It  does  not  appear  necessary  to  say  much  in  defence  of  the  anomaly  (although  contrary 
to  almost  unbroken  custom)  of  these  prefatory  remarks  appearing  in  a  different  language 
from  the  book  to  which  they  relate.  Even  vvhen  Latin  was  the  only  language  of  the 
learaed,  and  in  the  hands  of  those  •nho  wielded  it  as  masters,  it  served  but  poorly  to 
exj)ress  modern  barbarous  names  and  customs,  and  modes  of  thinking  which  we  woukl 
not  willingly  change  for  what  is  classical.  It  is  needless  to  enquire  flhether  this  arose 
from  the  sbgular  unwieldiness  of  that  kmguage,  or  that  nations  must  liave  common 
principles  of  thought,  feeling,  aud  action,  to  render  the  language  of  tlie  one  fit  for 
expressing  the  sentiments  of  the  other.  The  present  work  can  hardly  come  into  tlie 
hands  of  foreigners,  for  whora  it  would  have  no  interest ;  and  now,  when  Latin  is 
superseded  even  in  works  of  science  by  another  and  more  universal  tongue,  it  ap- 
proaches  to  afFectation  to  cramp  the  free  coiirse  of  tliought  and  give  ambiguity  to  its 
expression,  by  using  a  dead  language,  merely  from  deference  to  okl  editorial  usage.
